Award.AwardTitle: Innovative Processes for Fabricating Three-Dimensional Ultrathin Foams with Enhanced Thermal Properties

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Three-dimensional (3D) ultrathin foams of two-dimensional (2D) materials hold high potential for a variety of applications, including structure reinforcement, thermal management, and energy storage. However, their industrial adoption has been limited due to the substantial difficulties in controlling the pore size and strut wall thickness of the foams to desired dimensions with existing materials processing technologies. This award supports research to address this challenge, by investigating an original and novel process that can lead to highly controllable growth of 3D foams with tunable pore sizes. This research will accelerate the processing technology of 3D porous materials with substantial impact on an array of applications including energy storage, thermal management, and flexible electronics. It will also provide opportunities for educating the next generation workforce to enhance the competitiveness of the US in materials processing and manufacturing technologies.

The goal of this research is to investigate an innovative process for manufacturing 3D foam architectures of 2D ultrathin graphite (UG) as well as similar foams of dielectric 2D hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) with controllable pore sizes between 1 micon and 100 microns, and tunable strut wall thickness from 1 to 1000 nm. The materials processing method consists of a new approach for fabricating Ni foams as catalytic templates with reduced pore sizes or multiple level porosity, an energy effective and rapid RF induction heating method for growth of large-scale UG and h-BN materials, and an efficient Ni etching process. This work will also establish a fundamental understanding of the effects of pore size, wall thickness, grain boundaries and structure on the thermal properties of UG and h-BN foams and composites. New knowledge in materials processing will be obtained for manufacturing 3D multilevel porous UG and h-BN materials with enhanced thermal management properties. The understanding and knowledge resulting from this work will also potentially lead to a general approach for manufacturing a variety of other 2D materials into 3D foam structures.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative research successfully realized original schemes toward synthesizing multilevel porous 2D materials made of graphene/graphite and hexagonal boron nitride (HBN) by engineering Cu/Ni three-dimensional (3D) foams as catalysts. The research strategically produced a second level of micropores with tunable pore sizes less than 10 ?m on existing porous foam structures with ~100 ?m microstruts. Furthermore, the entire 3D surface area can be substantially enhanced by either electroplating dense arrays of micro/nanobranches or infiltrating low-cost fine Ni powders to utilize the 3D space of the interconnected micropores in existing foams. The fabrication strategies are scalable and lead to a new paradigm for rational design and manufacturing of hierarchically porous foams with desired features made of various materials. Inexpensive and industry compatible techniques, such as electrochemistry, sintering, and chemical vapor deposition, were employed. The research has resulted in multiple US and international patents submitted or granted.

This project also addressed a ubiquitous problem encountered in materials processing research, specifically the numerous experiments that are required to obtain the desired morphologies and structures of a design material. In this work, the correlations between essential experimental parameters and the obtained features and morphologies have been established by exploring artificial machine learning with a finite amount of experimental data. The models produced in this effort could be readily applied toward predictable fabrication of many types of materials.

The ability to control the pore size and microstructure of the porous graphitic foams led to a considerable increase of the thermal conductivity of the graphitic foam structures grown by the chemical vapor deposition process. For example, at a still low graphite volume fraction of less than 10%, the graphitic foam synthesized on sintered low-cost sintered nickel templates can be employed as a filler materials to increase the effective thermal conductivity of phase change materials by nearly two orders of magnitude.

Overall, the materials processing strategy is not only useful for creating 3D porous materials with enhanced thermal conductivity for applications such as thermal management and thermal energy storage, but also can be applied toward electrochemical energy storage, flexible electronics, and water treatment. This research also offered a multidisciplinary training ground for the next generation scientists and engineers in the field of nanomanufacturing, artificial-intelligence-assisted materials design, thermal properties measurement, and impacted the K12 students in campus-wide outreach events.


Last Modified: 12/30/2020
Modified by: Donglei (Emma) Fan
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This collaborative research successfully realized original schemes toward synthesizing multilevel porous 2D materials made of graphene/graphite and hexagonal boron nitride (HBN) by engineering Cu/Ni three-dimensional (3D) foams as catalysts. The research strategically produced a second level of micropores with tunable pore sizes less than 10 ?m on existing porous foam structures with ~100 ?m microstruts. Furthermore, the entire 3D surface area can be substantially enhanced by either electroplating dense arrays of micro/nanobranches or infiltrating low-cost fine Ni powders to utilize the 3D space of the interconnected micropores in existing foams. The fabrication strategies are scalable and lead to a new paradigm for rational design and manufacturing of hierarchically porous foams with desired features made of various materials. Inexpensive and industry compatible techniques, such as electrochemistry, sintering, and chemical vapor deposition, were employed. The research has resulted in multiple US and international patents submitted or granted. This project also addressed a ubiquitous problem encountered in materials processing research, specifically the numerous experiments that are required to obtain the desired morphologies and structures of a design material. In this work, the correlations between essential experimental parameters and the obtained features and morphologies have been established by exploring artificial machine learning with a finite amount of experimental data. The models produced in this effort could be readily applied toward predictable fabrication of many types of materials. The ability to control the pore size and microstructure of the porous graphitic foams led to a considerable increase of the thermal conductivity of the graphitic foam structures grown by the chemical vapor deposition process. For example, at a still low graphite volume fraction of less than 10%, the graphitic foam synthesized on sintered low-cost sintered nickel templates can be employed as a filler materials to increase the effective thermal conductivity of phase change materials by nearly two orders of magnitude. Overall, the materials processing strategy is not only useful for creating 3D porous materials with enhanced thermal conductivity for applications such as thermal management and thermal energy storage, but also can be applied toward electrochemical energy storage, flexible electronics, and water treatment. This research also offered a multidisciplinary training ground for the next generation scientists and engineers in the field of nanomanufacturing, artificial-intelligence-assisted materials design, thermal properties measurement, and impacted the K12 students in campus-wide outreach events.
